# The New York Times

# Trump's Vision For the Border: Send In Troops

Allies Seek Legal Way to Deploy at Home

This article is by Charlie Savage. Jonathan S. Sommerville and Maggie Heasbro.

WASHINGTON — During the turbulent winter of 2020, President Donald J. Trump argued in the military and legal adverts, calling them “heavier” for objecting to his idea of using federal troops to suppress outbreaks of violence during the nationwide protests after the police murder of George Floyd.

It wasn’t the only time Mr. Trump was in attendance of using the military for domestic law enforcement — a practice that would carry profound implications for civil liberties and for the traditional constraints on federal power. He repeatedly raised the idea of using troops to secure border states, and even proposed shooting both violent protesters and undocumented migrants in the legs, former aides have said.

In his first term as office, Mr. Trump never realized he equated violence with using troops to secure the law’s civil, but after his loss in August, a return to power, he said he would not use troops to secure the military for a range of domestic law enforcement.

In the 2020 election, he said, he would not use troops to secure the military for a range of domestic law enforcement.

In the past few years, he has said he would not use troops to secure the military for a range of domestic law enforcement.
